course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Global Information Infrastructure and Policy
course.description: This course provides a panorama review of the global information infrastructure from technology, policy, social and business perspectives. Key issues include next generation information infrastructure, Internet of things, anti-spamming legislation, universal service, digital convergence, network interconnection, the WTO’s agreement on telecommunications, cloud computing, green ICT, and regulatory environment of multimedia services. It will also address the increasing importance of Web 2.0-enabled information infrastructure in business innovation.

reviews.author: enigma
reviews.title: Nice professor. Intense schedule.
reviews.comment_content:
The course is only available in winter semester as a 2-week intensive course.

As seen from the course description, the course content are mostly above technology of communication. The course focuses on wireless communication technologies such as mobile phone service, WiFi and its related technical issues. Some history of telecommunication, especially of the US and HK will be covered.

Personally I think the content of the course is quite intriguing. Living In a metropolitan nowadays you may find wireless communications compulsory, but you may not know how the quality is assured. The course provides loads of detailed background of telecommunications and allows students to appreciate the technologies and rationales of policies of wireless communications in different regions.

The course is suitable for people who really prefer learn new stuff  to good grade, though grade is quite fair too.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Accent: although the professor is from mainland China, his accent of speaking English is not difficult to understand.

Context: The professor is so knowledgeable in this ground of study. This may be the reason that he can provide loads of interesting facts and examples during class. He even shares his own research contents and share his opinions to the class on some issues of information infrastructure and policy.
reviews.comment_grading:
Both midterm and final above 1 SD.
Grade B+
Not as good as expected but it's fair as the class is competitive.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 Midterm:
An online take-home quiz at the end of week 1. Answers can be found from lecture notes and facts from lecture. You should make sure that your answers are all correct.

1 Final:
Close book exam at the end of week 2. Memorize some important facts and significant history background.

reviews.comment_content: The content is not difficult to handle. Although the course is run in just two-week time, I don't feel suffocated since many examples of the course is from real-world, like Japan DOCOMO, Korea, United States AT&T.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Video available after class. Some long questions are based on what professor said in class, which is not written on lecture notes. MC+Fill in the blanks+Long question (around 30+30+40). The long question are not asking you to write essays, just listing of points.
Midterm is take-home canvas. You can try google them, but I am sure you will not find them. I see someone asking them in some technical forum, but I see that these questions are very soon being banned by the forum administrator (they may know you are asking exam questions....)
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair. Probably only one guy got A+, which requires 95+ in both midterm and final. I scored A (all 90+) and am the sixth highest in class. In my failed attempt to ask for A+, the professor replied that the other 4 people higher than me is also A, who have overall 92-95 marks based on what I saw from TA during paper checking session. I don't know the rest.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not heavy. If you understand course material during lectures, you will certainly score high, Pay more attention to making the cheat sheet for the final exam. It helps a lot.
First half only covers first half questions
Second half only covers after-midterm materials though some final questions have questions about materials before midterms since some lecture materials are the same in both half.

reviews.author: Akaza
reviews.title: An unnecessarily intensely scheduled course during winter
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures :-
1) Introduction to information infrastructure
2) Digital technology and convergence, and wireless communications.
3) Next generation information infrastructure
4) The business and socioeconomic effects of information infrastructure
5) Innovation 2.0
6) Diffusion of innovation, the adoption of SMS in HK and China
7) Telecommunications policy and regulations, argument over natural monopoly, necessity and feasibility of information infrastructure competition
8) Organisational restructuring of information infrastructure
9) Network interconnection, from universal service to universal choice (local fixed network competition in HK)
10) Foreign direct investment in telecommunications and WTO's basic telecommunications agreement

I would say 30% of the course is common sense, and the rest requires you to memorise rather than understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are actually quite helpful, because the slides are rather abstract and don't contain explanations of the concepts or anything. So I would suggest you to at least watch the recordings like I did (btw, I didn't attend a single lecture). Furthermore, his English is better than most HKUST professors so that helps as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme is quite favourable but the grades are competitive (unduly so) - 50% mid-term and 50% finals. I say favourable because the mid-term exam is a 3-day take-home over-the-weekend canvas quiz with unlimited attempts. Therefore, chances that you will get around full marks for mid-term and hence secure the 50% of the grade are high. Well, of course thats only a given if you actually put it in some effort despite the fact that most answers are found on the lecture slides and i'm sure many people just use command+F. However, this also means that other people will get a good score on their mid-terms, consequently making the grading competitive.

Nevertheless, the mean for the mid terms was surprisingly low given these conditions - 82.7/100. The high score was 95.5/100 and I attained 93/100.  I expected the mean to be at-least 90%.
(FYI, the upper quartile was 92.8/100 hence out of 130 people, 25% of the people were potentially in the A-range, including myself. However, i am not sure if the professor assigned the entire UQ as A-range).

The finals did not at all include the content from mid-term, and not even indirectly so, hence you can practically forget everything you learned before mid-terms, and it wouldn't affect your understanding of the content for finals. Personally, I thought the whole exam set-up was absolutely ridiculous (absurd, almost laughable), not the exam itself since it was quite easy but rather the set-up. Although the exam took place in-person, "in order to save paper and go green, the exam will take place on canvas as a quiz" - professor. At first thought, you might think that it's acceptable and perhaps not even a bad idea, but trust me I thought so too as well until 40min into the exam. The exam is 3 hours long, and I saw people leaving after 30 minutes .............without actually submitting the quiz lol. The incompetent TA did not even bother checking if they submitted the quiz, so I'm sure they just went to an isolated place and finished the quiz while looking at all their notes and by searching on the internet.

Anyways, the exam was rather straight-forward and I believe you can secure a good grade even without cheating if you attend all lectures because the slides are rather abstract. The score wasn't released, but I somehow got an A. I was confident before even going to the finals, but after seeing that ludicrousness, I lost hope and thought I would end up getting B-range because everyone who cheated is going to get a very high score, hence manipulating the grade curve.
reviews.comment_workload: As the other reviews also say, this is a very intense course and does have a relatively heavy workload given the time-span of the course. However, since the content for finals is so different from mid-terms, you can just focus on the topics after-mid terms which reduces your overall workload by half.

reviews.author: Thomas Tse
reviews.title: ISOM 2400
reviews.comment_content:
This course is a 2-week intensive course, with 3.5hr (1.5hr + 20 min break + 1.5hr) lectures from Monday to Friday.
In terms of content, the part before mid-term is mainly about the technology involved in telecommunications and some history about it.  But this part is quite easy to understand because this course only covers the basic of them, and the mid-term is an open-book assignment, so don't worry about it.
The part after the mid-term is mainly about telecommunications policy and some real-life examples.

Content:
- Introduction to the Information Infrastructure
- Digital Convergence; Wireless Communications and Spectrum Regulation
- The Next Generation Information Infrastructure
- Business and Socioeconomic Implications of Information Infrastructure
- Web 2.0 and Innovation
- Diffusion of Telecommunications Services
- Theoretical Framework of Information Infrastructure Deregulation
- Organizational Restructuring of Information Infrastructure
- Network Interconnection; Local Network Competition in Hong Kong
- Foreign Direct Investment in Telecommunications and WTO’s Basic Telecommunications Agreement
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is very friendly and he sometimes gives out interesting facts about himself and the lecture content. It is quite fun to attend his lectures. Though it is a 3.5hr lecture, luckily we had a 20min (sometimes 30 min) break.
The professor likes to have some interactions within the class, sometimes he would ask students to answer some questions, and sometimes he would just ask students to have a discussion among themselves.
The professor has very little accent only, which will not affect your learning at all.
reviews.comment_grading:
- mid-term assignment (50%)
- final exam (50%)

The Mid-term is an open-book assignment and students need to finish it within the weekend.
The final exam is a close-book exam, students need to do it on Canvas on campus. We can bring a cheat sheet (1 A4 sheet, both pages), 3 hrs to work on the 64 questions.

reviews.title: Good course intense schedule
reviews.comment_content: The contents are very interesting. But it may be very burdensome since it covers hell lot of contents in 2 to 3 weeks.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is from mainland, but his accent is very easy to understande because it studied in UK. He know a lot of things about the content, and his lecture is not confusing. Everything is clear.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair. Everything comes from the lecture slide. The exams have 4 parts. T/F, Multiple choise, Fill in the blank, and essay. It is very easy to get a good grade in midterm since it is an open book online exam for three days. Everyone uses ctrl+F in pdf file to find the solution.

But the final is not easy. The final is very tight. Each sesson gives about 30 minutes, and each problem must be solved in one minute. Otherwise, you will not have time to finish the exam. The final result is not released, but if you are able to answer all of the problems, you can get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload depends on the style of your study. If you want to get an A range grade, you have to memorize all the matrials. And the workload will be huge. But if you want to get an B range grade, professors lecture, and reading the ppt once will be enough.

reviews.comment_teaching:

However, in fact, Prof. Xu has made an interesting speech and many figures to keep you out of boredom.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not too good and not too bad. Since this course is quite competitive, the grade can come out can be lower, or higher than your expectation.

Grading Scheme:
Midterm (Open book, 50%)
Final (50%)

Got 79.5 in midterm (mean: 77.8)
The Final exam is unknown since Prof. has already said not to release the score.

Final grade: B-
The reason for such a low final grade can be reasoned as, again, this course is competitive. This could be due to the fact that I got below mean in the final, which even overcome the 1.7 marks above mean advantage in midterm.

It is heard that A-range is for the top 25% of students.

But for the final, it would be much harder. Even you are prepared with cheat sheets, there can still be tricky questions.

reviews.author: UB0000
reviews.title: Not a bad choice in Winter Term in terms of grade
reviews.comment_content:
The first half of the course is rather technical, about the technology and application involve in telecom industry. The second part is related to some economics and policy development in the industry. Not really useful or interesting unless you want to work in telecom industry.
Some reading is provided, but it is not necessary to read them.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Xu's accent is not perfect, but quite satisfactory from my experience. It is not too difficult to understand and follow his words. Also, he tries to interact with students and invite external guest to give us a sharing, which may help you to understand more about the current telecom industry. Fortunately the sharing is out of exam syllabus.

For Mr Ng, the TA, the only problem is that sometimes he upload the lecture materials just before the lecture. His main duty is to help Prof Xu.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% midterm, 50% final.

Midterm: Last for 48 hours, "open everything", but only focus on the first half of lecture materials. You may prepare by scanning the PowerPoint briefly.
Mean: 80.8/100 Highest:98/100 My score: 94.5/100

Final: Close note, last for 1.5 hours. You may bring a 2-sided A4 cheat sheet. You may want to recite some important points in the lecture and slides as the time is tight.
Mean: 66.5/100 Highest:95/100 My score: 88.5/100

Final grade: A+ (I didn't have any relevant background but I did invest time in the course.)
reviews.comment_workload:
The course become less intensive this year. as it turns into a 3-week course instead of 2-week, excluding exam. Although we still have 10 3-hour lecture, we have more time to revise for midterm and final, plus a day of break.
You need not worry about working with hw or project everyday, but you still need to revise the lecture if you want a good grade.

reviews.author: grindingalways
reviews.title: Good course to take if you want to boost your GPA in winter!
reviews.comment_content:
You can find the content from others' reviews, but basically, the first part is something very technical, and some are actually overlapping with the content of ELEC1010 so if you have taken ELEC1010 before you would feel much easier to understand. And then some lectures cover the historical side of how telecommunications develop over the years, including changes in policy. There are also lectures that talk about somewhat more interesting topics, such as diffusion of innovation and innovation 2.0.

But after all, the content to me is very boring, and I had a hard time trying to focus during class so I skipped all of them and watched lecture videos in the end.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Xu is a nice and friendly professor. I actually think his accent is a bit hard to understand, so I had to frequently pause the lecture recordings and go back to listen again. And the reason why I tried to catch every word that he said is that the mid-term and final exams cover more than just the lecture slides. Sometimes Professor could share more information in class and they would be tested as well, so be aware of that. Anyway, he replied to emails very promptly. I have sent emails to him at midnight and he responded to me after a short while.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term and Final both occupy 50% respectively for the final grade. They are non-cummulative. Mid-term is a take-home one that lasts for a couple of days, while for final it's supposedly taken at school but due to COVID it's switched to online (closed book, but 1 A4 chear sheet, both sides allowed). You may send email to TA to ask the specifics of your score breakdown as well as distribution.

Mid-term (50%)
Mean: 80.83/100
Me: 98/100

Final (50%)
Mean: 66.5/100
SD: 16.2
Me: 83.5/100

Final Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Harsh to me. As I was taking an internship as well, the workload from the course is very huge given its intensive nature. Each lecture note nearly consists of 100 pages, and the exams are more like a memorization game, so I rushed and stayed up all night to make the cheat sheet for the final exam, and it was very painful. But I think efforts will certainly pay off for this course!

You won't sleep in the cinema, don't you?

reviews.comment_grading: I don't have anything to say about this...not a math course..but if you used those concepts and examples you should be fine..
reviews.comment_workload: This is probably the course with the lightest workload in terms of...tangible work. One mid-term (assignment) which you need to do on canvas, and one final exam. But you have to devote the afternoon of all weekdays (Mon to Fri) for two weeks, and the after lecture time for revision. That is the hidden workload.

reviews.author: Timmy Chung
reviews.comment_content:
The first part is mostly about some technical knowledge like how the telegraph works and the future prospect of technology. Most of the contents are not updated (there are still 3G in the PowerPoint).

The second part is about the economic value of telecommunication and the regulations. It is more interesting in my opinion.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Xu teaching is alright, his English is very clear and you can easily understand what he said. He adds some videos to make the lessons less boring but 3 hours lecture is still exhausting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 50%
Mean 80.8/100
Final 50%
Mean 66.5/100

There are T/F, multiple-choice, filling blank and essay. Mid-term questions are alright and you can find most of the answers by searching the PowerPoint. However, some of the questions are not included in the PowerPoint but taught by the professor in class.
